     373             : } // namespace span_details
     374             : 
     375             : /**
     376             :  * Span - slices for C++
     377             :  *
     378             :  * Span implements Rust's slice concept for C++. It's called "Span" instead of
     379             :  * "Slice" to follow the naming used in C++ Core Guidelines.
     380             :  *
     381             :  * A Span wraps a pointer and a length that identify a non-owning view to a
     382             :  * contiguous block of memory of objects of the same type. Various types,
     383             :  * including (pre-decay) C arrays, XPCOM strings, nsTArray, mozilla::Array,
     384             :  * mozilla::Range and contiguous standard-library containers, auto-convert
     385             :  * into Spans when attempting to pass them as arguments to methods that take
     386             :  * Spans. MakeSpan() functions can be used for explicit conversion in other
     387             :  * contexts. (Span itself autoconverts into mozilla::Range.)
     388             :  *
     389             :  * Like Rust's slices, Span provides safety against out-of-bounds access by
     390             :  * performing run-time bound checks. However, unlike Rust's slices, Span
     391             :  * cannot provide safety against use-after-free.
     392             :  *
     393             :  * (Note: Span is like Rust's slice only conceptually. Due to the lack of
     394             :  * ABI guarantees, you should still decompose spans/slices to raw pointer
     395             :  * and length parts when crossing the FFI.)
     396             :  *
     397             :  * In addition to having constructors and MakeSpan() functions that take
     398             :  * various well-known types, a Span for an arbitrary type can be constructed
     399             :  * (via constructor or MakeSpan()) from a pointer and a length or a pointer
     400             :  * and another pointer pointing just past the last element.
     401             :  *
     402             :  * A Span<const char> or Span<const char16_t> can be obtained for const char*
     403             :  * or const char16_t pointing to a zero-terminated string using the
     404             :  * MakeStringSpan() function. Corresponding implicit constructor does not exist
     405             :  * in order to avoid accidental construction in cases where const char* or
     406             :  * const char16_t* do not point to a zero-terminated string.
     407             :  *
     408             :  * Span has methods that follow the Mozilla naming style and methods that
     409             :  * don't. The methods that follow the Mozilla naming style are meant to be
     410             :  * used directly from Mozilla code. The methods that don't are meant for
     411             :  * integration with C++11 range-based loops and with meta-programming that
     412             :  * expects the same methods that are found on the standard-library
     413             :  * containers. For example, to decompose a Span into its parts in Mozilla
     414             :  * code, use Elements() and Length() (as with nsTArray) instead of data()
     415             :  * and size() (as with std::vector).
     416             :  *
     417             :  * The pointer and length wrapped by a Span cannot be changed after a Span has
     418             :  * been created. When new values are required, simply create a new Span. Span
     419             :  * has a method called Subspan() that works analogously to the Substring()
     420             :  * method of XPCOM strings taking a start index and an optional length. As a
     421             :  * Mozilla extension (relative to Microsoft's gsl::span that mozilla::Span is
     422             :  * based on), Span has methods From(start), To(end) and FromTo(start, end)
     423             :  * that correspond to Rust's &slice[start..], &slice[..end] and
     424             :  * &slice[start..end], respectively. (That is, the end index is the index of
     425             :  * the first element not to be included in the new subspan.)
     426             :  *
     427             :  * When indicating a Span that's only read from, const goes inside the type
     428             :  * parameter. Don't put const in front of Span. That is:
     429             :  * size_t ReadsFromOneSpanAndWritesToAnother(Span<const uint8_t> aReadFrom,
     430             :  *                                           Span<uint8_t> aWrittenTo);
     431             :  *
     432             :  * Any Span<const T> can be viewed as Span<const uint8_t> using the function
     433             :  * AsBytes(). Any Span<T> can be viewed as Span<uint8_t> using the function
     434             :  * AsWritableBytes().
     435             :  */
     436             : template<class ElementType, size_t Extent>
     437             : class Span
     438             : {
     439             : public:
     440             :   // constants and types
     441             :   using element_type = ElementType;
     442             :   using index_type = size_t;
     443             :   using pointer = element_type*;
     444             :   using reference = element_type&;
     445             : 
     446             :   using iterator =
     447             :     span_details::span_iterator<Span<ElementType, Extent>, false>;
     448             :   using const_iterator =
     449             :     span_details::span_iterator<Span<ElementType, Extent>, true>;
     450             :   using reverse_iterator = std::reverse_iterator<iterator>;
     451             :   using const_reverse_iterator = std::reverse_iterator<const_iterator>;
     452             : 
     453             :   constexpr static const index_type extent = Extent;
     454             : 
     455             :   // [Span.cons], Span constructors, copy, assignment, and destructor
     456             :   // "Dependent" is needed to make "span_details::enable_if_t<(Dependent || Extent == 0 || Extent == mozilla::MaxValue<size_t>::value)>" SFINAE,
     457             :   // since "span_details::enable_if_t<(Extent == 0 || Extent == mozilla::MaxValue<size_t>::value)>" is ill-formed when Extent is neither of the extreme values.
     458             :   /**
     459             :    * Constructor with no args.
     460             :    */
     461             :   template<
     462             :     bool Dependent = false,
     463             :     class = span_details::enable_if_t<
     464             :       (Dependent || Extent == 0 || Extent == mozilla::MaxValue<size_t>::value)>>
     465           0 :   constexpr Span()
     466           0 :     : storage_(nullptr, span_details::extent_type<0>())
     467             :   {
     468           0 :   }
     469             : 
     470             :   /**
     471             :    * Constructor for nullptr.
     472             :    */
     473             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(std::nullptr_t) : Span() {}
     474             : 
     475             :   /**
     476             :    * Constructor for pointer and length.
     477             :    */
     478             :   constexpr Span(pointer aPtr, index_type aLength)
     479           0 :     : storage_(aPtr, aLength)
     480             :   {
     481             :   }
     482             : 
     483             :   /**
     484             :    * Constructor for start pointer and pointer past end.
     485             :    */
     486             :   constexpr Span(pointer aStartPtr, pointer aEndPtr)
     487             :     : storage_(aStartPtr, std::distance(aStartPtr, aEndPtr))
     488             :   {
     489             :   }
     490             : 
     491             :   /**
     492             :    * Constructor for C array.
     493             :    */
     494             :   template<size_t N>
     495             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(element_type (&aArr)[N])
     496             :     : storage_(&aArr[0], span_details::extent_type<N>())
     497             :   {
     498             :   }
     499             : 
     500             :   /**
     501             :    * Constructor for std::array.
     502             :    */
     503             :   template<size_t N,
     504             :            class ArrayElementType = span_details::remove_const_t<element_type>>
     505             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(std::array<ArrayElementType, N>& aArr)
     506             :     : storage_(&aArr[0], span_details::extent_type<N>())
     507             :   {
     508             :   }
     509             : 
     510             :   /**
     511             :    * Constructor for const std::array.
     512             :    */
     513             :   template<size_t N>
     514             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(
     515             :     const std::array<span_details::remove_const_t<element_type>, N>& aArr)
     516             :     : storage_(&aArr[0], span_details::extent_type<N>())
     517             :   {
     518             :   }
     519             : 
     520             :   /**
     521             :    * Constructor for mozilla::Array.
     522             :    */
     523             :   template<size_t N,
     524             :            class ArrayElementType = span_details::remove_const_t<element_type>>
     525             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(mozilla::Array<ArrayElementType, N>& aArr)
     526             :     : storage_(&aArr[0], span_details::extent_type<N>())
     527             :   {
     528             :   }
     529             : 
     530             :   /**
     531             :    * Constructor for const mozilla::Array.
     532             :    */
     533             :   template<size_t N>
     534             :   constexpr MOZ_IMPLICIT Span(
     535             :     const mozilla::Array<span_details::remove_const_t<element_type>, N>& aArr)
     536             :     : storage_(&aArr[0], span_details::extent_type<N>())
     537             :   {
     538             :   }
     539             : 
     540             :   /**
     541             :    * Constructor for mozilla::UniquePtr holding an array and length.
     542             :    */
     543             :   template<class ArrayElementType = std::add_pointer<element_type>>
     544             :   constexpr Span(const mozilla::UniquePtr<ArrayElementType>& aPtr,
     545             :                  index_type aLength)
     546             :     : storage_(aPtr.get(), aLength)
     547             :   {
     548             :   }
     549             : 
     550             :   // NB: the SFINAE here uses .data() as a incomplete/imperfect proxy for the requirement
     551             :   // on Container to be a contiguous sequence container.

     895             : // if we only supported compilers with good constexpr support then
